claim: Electronic Arts did profit from Metroid sales.

supporting.text: Electronic Arts (EA) is not the publisher or developer of the Metroid franchise; Nintendo owns and publishes Metroid games.

attacks.text: Electronic Arts (EA) is not the publisher or developer of the Metroid franchise; Nintendo owns and publishes Metroid games.
EA could have indirectly profited from Metroid sales through licensing deals or merchandise partnerships with Nintendo.
There is no public record of EA having any licensing or partnership agreements related to the Metroid franchise.
EA might have received royalties from Metroid sales if they provided middleware or development tools used in the games.
Nintendo typically develops Metroid games in-house or with trusted partners, making the use of EA tools unlikely.

supporting.text: EA's financial reports and public statements do not mention any revenue or profit from Metroid-related sales.

attacks.text: EA's financial reports and public statements do not mention any revenue or profit from Metroid-related sales.
EA may have profited indirectly through partnerships or licensing agreements not explicitly detailed in public reports.
EA has no known partnerships or licensing agreements related to Metroid, making indirect profit unlikely.
Financial reports may omit minor revenue streams, including small-scale Metroid-related sales.
EA's financial disclosures are comprehensive and legally required to include all material revenue sources.

supporting.text: There is no evidence of licensing agreements between EA and Nintendo for the Metroid franchise.

attacks.text: There is no evidence of licensing agreements between EA and Nintendo for the Metroid franchise.
EA could have profited indirectly through third-party distribution or merchandising deals involving Metroid.
Third-party distribution or merchandising deals would still require some form of licensing or agreement traceable to Nintendo, which lacks evidence.
EA might have acquired partial rights to Metroid through acquisitions of other companies, bypassing direct agreements with Nintendo.
No public records or credible reports suggest EA has ever held any rights to the Metroid franchise through acquisitions.

supporting.text: Historical sales data for Metroid games are attributed to Nintendo or its subsidiaries, not EA.

attacks.text: Historical sales data for Metroid games are attributed to Nintendo or its subsidiaries, not EA.
EA may have indirectly profited from Metroid sales through licensing or distribution agreements.
There is no public record of EA having any licensing or distribution agreements related to Metroid.
EA could have profited from Metroid sales if they were involved in porting or remastering any Metroid games.
No Metroid games have been ported or remastered by EA, and all such projects have been handled by Nintendo or its partners.
